Award.AwardTitle: Interactions Between Representation Theory and Algebraic Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The conference "Interactions between representation theory and algebraic geometry," will take place at the University of Chicago, August 21-25, 2017. It will be a major gathering of researchers in these two interacting branches of mathematics. Representation theory is the algebraic study of symmetries in geometry and physics and is at the crossroads of many important areas of modern mathematics. Algebraic geometry is concerned with the study of shapes that can be described using polynomial equations, and with applying geometric ideas to commutative algebra and number theory. In the past decades, some of the most important results in representation theory have been obtained by applying ideas and methods from algebraic geometry, and conversely many important problems in algebraic geometry have benefited from applying representation theory. The conference will feature one-hour lectures by leading experts in the field, poster presentations, and evening talks by junior mathematicians. The conference will stimulate productive interactions between mathematicians in diverse fields and career stages, including Ph.D. students and postdoctoral researchers.

The conference will address recent developments in the interconnected areas of representation theory and algebraic geometry, as well as related subjects, including p-adic Hodge theory, arithmetic geometry and non-commutative algebra. In particular, cutting-edge research related to categorification, symplectic resolutions, quantization, D-modules, quiver varities and the Langlands program will be presented. The conference aims not only to disseminate this research but to make it accessible to junior mathematicians. The webpage is https://sites.google.com/site/2017uchicagomathconference/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Algebraic geometry is a branch of mathematics devoted to the study of geometric objects that can be described using polynomials, and hence algebra. Representation theory is an area of mathematics that seeks to understand symmetries of spaces or structures and their generalizations, often arising from geometry or physics, using matrices and vectors. The conference Interactions between representation theory and algebraic geometry, which took place at the University of Chicago from August 21 to August 25, 2017, was a major international gathering that included world renowned experts, with the goal of fostering new discoveries at the intersection of those two branches of mathematics. It was attended by about 150 participants, mostly from major universities in the US, but also from abroad. More than half of the participants were graduate students and postdoctoral researchers; some of them prepared posters to disseminate their research, and others volunteered to give introductory talks as preparation for the main lectures that were delivered by expert researchers. That conference thus served the purpose of initiating the next generation of mathematicians to certain aspects of current high level research in algebraic geometry and representation theory, as well as bringing together top experts in the active areas of research and making them available to many American researchers.
